units.name: ChaosCultist
units.description: Mass infantry unit that can clear tiles, found cities and sacrifice itself to the Dark Gods.
units.flavour: The cultists of Chaos can be found, in one form or another, almost anywhere the Imperium has spread. At first glance, they are indistinguishable from normal men, but under their clothes, their flesh is tattooed and branded with sigils that hurt the eyes of any faithful who look upon them. When the Chaos Space Marines come to a planet, the true colours of the cultists are revealed. The powers of darkness are ever quick to promise glory, and even the lowliest initiate knows that to fight alongside such legendary warriors is to court the gaze of the gods.

units.name: ChaosLandRaider
units.description: Massively armoured and heavily armed transport unit.
units.flavour: The Chaos Land Raider is the heaviest ground vehicle in a Chaos Space Marine army. Its adamantine and ceramite plates can withstand all but the deadliest anti-tank weaponry, and the blessings of the Warpsmiths keep it at peak efficiency. The twin lascannons mounted in each sponson make short work of other vehicles that would dare to attempt to stop its rampage.

units.name: ChaosLord
units.description: Hero unit that returns damage to attackers and slays units low on hitpoints.
units.flavour: A Chaos Lord is a tyrannical warrior king who lives to bathe in the blood of worlds. He strives to bring whole star systems to their knees in the name of his patron deities. Typified by merciless ambition and fierce pride, many of these champions of disorder were once noble Chapter Masters and Captains of the Adeptus Astartes, but long years of unremitting war have twisted their souls beyond recovery.

units.name: ChaosSpaceMarine
units.description: Versatile infantry unit.
units.flavour: Ever since the Horus Heresy, Space Marines have been tempted by the path of Chaos, whether for selfish reasons or great ideals. Sundered from the Imperium, having turned their backs on the Emperor, these warriors know that there can be no peace for them, neither forgiveness nor absolution. They are wholly committed to the path they now tread, for good or ill, and they can expect no quarter from former battle-brothers.

units.name: ChaosRhino
units.description: Armoured transport vehicle that can self-repair.
units.flavour: The Rhino is the most common transport of the Space Marines, and the same can be said of the Heretic Astartes, for this machine is so ruggedly constructed it can see hundreds of years of warfare and still function at peak efficiency. The tank's chassis is based upon a Standard Template Construct, meaning that it is relatively simple to build, maintain and repair. Over the ten thousand years since the Long War began, the Rhino has seen continued use as the favoured transport of the Chaos Space Marines. They will even go so far as to loot them from defeated Imperial armies, though they will burn them clean of Imperial insignia as quickly as possible and festoon the stolen vehicles with spikes, blades and gory trophies taken from the dismembered bodies of their previous owners.

units.name: ChaosSpawn
units.description: Fast melee infantry unit that mutates each turn.
units.flavour: Although physically powerful and extremely resilient, Chaos Spawn are insane, mewling creatures with no mental powers or self-awareness. Their former intelligence has been sacrificed to their failed ambition. Many a champion of great promise has ended up as a seething mound of bone and blubber, monstrous and screaming with lunatic rage.

units.name: DaemonPrince
units.description: Monstrous hero that cripples foes with psychic powers before clawing them to death.
units.flavour: Daemon Princes are infernal monsters that tower over the mortals they lead to battle. These paragons of evil take many forms, though all exude a palpable aura of terror and power. In battle, a Daemon Prince strides through the pitiful bullets of the enemy without pause, his unnatural laughter driving men to the edge of fear. Warp energy sizzles from his eyes, and black flames curl from his mouth as he speaks dread phrases that kill as sure as any blade. These are creatures of nightmare—a living expression of Chaos given form.

units.name: DarkDisciple
units.description: Infantry unit that increases the defenses of Chaos units.
units.flavour: Dark Disciples carry profane accoutrements of their masters’ worship and parrot the fell words spoken in his baleful prayers. Many such disciples have been augmented to better serve in their role–their skin stretched out and inked with grim litanies, or their mouths fitted with Daemon-touched vox-grilles to project their voices into the warp. Amidst the din of combat they join their Dark Apostle’s chants, crying out for the Chaos Gods to manifest their blessings.

units.name: Defiler
units.description: Enormous walker unit with devastating melee and ranged weaponry.
units.flavour: Defilers are truly massive beasts of war, twice the size of most other Daemon Engines and with a temperament to match. The ground shivers and melts as they stalk towards their foes on six massive, segmented legs, their great pincer-arms twitching and snipping with an impatient need to slice through warm flesh. The Defiler's crab-like body supports a daemonic torso that carries an array of deadly weaponry, ranging from reaper autocannons to racks of highly explosive missiles. It is the battle cannon mounted in its chest turret, however, that is undoubtedly its most potent armament. Each hell-forged shell that thunders out from its growling muzzle is capable of crippling a squad of Space Marines in a single earth-shaking blast.

units.name: Havoc
units.description: Long range infantry unit that is more accurate while stationary.
units.flavour: Some Chaos Space Marine squads carry a high proportion of heavy weapons, the better to annihilate the hated foe. Known as Havocs, these squads provide devastating anti-infantry and anti-armour firepower, dominating large swathes of the battlefield with volley after punishing volley.

units.name: Headquarters
units.description: Headquarters unit that represents a city's defenses.
units.flavour: Even ten thousand years of heresy hasn’t entirely eliminated a Traitor’s training. Like their fellow Adeptus Astartes, Traitor Marines prefer to operate from a secure, well-constructed defensive position—preferably built by the Iron Warriors. This acts as a forward operations base for their raids and pillaging.

units.name: Helbrute
units.description: Walker unit that goes crazed when damaged.
units.flavour: Helbrutes are twisted mockeries of the Space Marine Dreadnoughts they used to be, combining the firepower of a small tank with the mind of a frenzied maniac. Each Helbrute holds a living creature within its plated metal chest—a Chaos Space Marine driven over the edge of madness by a never-ending cycle of war.

units.name: KhorneBerzerker
units.description: Melee infantry unit.
units.flavour: It was the gruesome experiments of Angron, Primarch of the World Eaters, that led to the creation of the first Berzerkers. By the ritual lobotomisation of his warriors, he removed all sense of fear and danger and then heightened the rush his soldiers experienced in combat. When the Legion swore itself to Khorne, the Berzerkers were no longer bound by Imperial battle doctrine and were given full rein to exercise their bloodthirsty skills. They have since become the ultimate close combat shock troops, entering an uncontrollable frenzy in the heat of battle.

units.name: Heldrake
units.description: Flying vehicle that excels against enemy aircraft.
units.flavour: Heldrakes are winged Daemon Engines that plummet out of the skies like living comets, hurtling towards enemy aircraft and crashing claws-first into them from above. Each is a vicious, hell-forged predator; a Heldrake takes cruel joy in diving down upon the unsuspecting air support of the enemy in order to shred them to pieces with its scything wings and rune-carved talons.

units.name: MasterOfPossession
units.description: Psyker hero unit that summons Daemons and supports allies.
units.flavour: Masters of Possession lead warbands of devoted warriors in pursuit of untold power. These sorcerous figures have mastered the darkest and most blasphemous lore: the art of using hosts of living flesh to house daemonic spirits. It is they who perform the profane ceremonies of binding that imbue the Daemonkin with their warp-born power. Gouging a breach in the fabric of realspace, the Master of Possession draws a willing entity from the immaterium, channelling its terrible energies into the body of a supplicant or the chassis of a war machine. So thoroughly are these dread figures steeped in blasphemous sorcery that where they walk, reality itself recoils.

units.name: Maulerfiend
units.description: Fast walker unit that reduces the melee attacks of adjacent units.
units.flavour: The Daemon Engines known as Maulerfiends thunder towards the foe like monstrous attack dogs loosed from the leash. Their eyes glow with balefire as ectoplasmic drool drizzles from their fanged maws. Their thick front limbs end in articulated claws powerful enough to tear a Dreadnought limb from limb. Should they catch a squad of infantry, they will scissor them apart or crush them into paste with a flex of their massive talons.

units.name: NoctilithCrown
units.description: Fortification that shields allied Chaos units and damages enemy psykers.
units.flavour: Noctilith Crowns form vital strongpoints, for these arcane devices can draw in the raw energy of Chaos itself.

units.name: Obliterator
units.description: Elite infantry unit with cyclable weapons.
units.flavour: The monstrous warriors of the Obliterator cults are a blasphemy against nature and Machine God alike. Their forms are so altered, so thoroughly conjoined with the tools of war, that every cell in their bodies thrills with a spark of mechanical life. Only the Dark Mechanicum have mastered the complete fusion of metal and flesh, melding the inert and the animate together on a spiritual level in order to form something far greater than mere cybernetics. Because of their Chaos-born powers, Obliterators are capable of not only absorbing weaponry into themselves, but also of manifesting munitions from their titanium-laced flesh.

units.name: Venomcrawler
units.description: Terrifying walker unit that consumes the souls of its enemies to restore its hitpoints.
units.flavour: Pounding forwards upon bladed limbs come the horrors known as Venomcrawlers. Grotesque amalgams of metal, flesh and daemonic entities, these monstrosities hiss and snarl as they scuttle towards their prey. Fleshy tongues flap from snarling maws and soulflayer tendrils lash back and forth, all tasting the air for the scent of their enemies' fear. As the Venomcrawlers continue to butcher, their fanged mouths gape ever wider, drawing the souls of those slain into their vast mechanical abdomens.

units.name: Warpsmith
units.description: Hero unit that supports vehicles and boosts the economy.
units.flavour: Warpsmiths are the masters of the machine. Most can trace their origins back to the priesthood of Mars, whether through the schisms of the Magi or the rigid doctrine of the Techmarines. However, where the Adeptus Mechanicus regard technology as sacrosanct, the Warpsmiths seek to subjugate and control it.

units.name: WarpTalon
units.description: Melee infantry unit that can warp across difficult terrain and blind unsuspecting enemies.
units.flavour: When a pack of Warp Talons emerges from the warp, it appears to those on the battlefield below as if daemonic warriors have burst out from nothingness into fiery, vengeful life. Like the stuff of nightmares, they plummet downwards in an explosion of warp fire, tearing into the foe with murderous intent.

buildings.name: Aircraft
buildings.description: Building that produces heldrakes as well as generates loyalty and influence.
buildings.flavour: 10,000 years ago the Heldrakes were fighter craft, piloted by the cream of the Adeptus Astartes. Now, they are hideous amalgams of man and machine, formed by millennia of war into dragon-like creatures that live to fight. This artificial eyrie allows the Warpsmiths and Master of Possession to monitor the Heldrakes and even attempt to replicate their age-old creation.

buildings.name: Cult
buildings.description: Building that produces special Chaos units and increases loyalty.
buildings.flavour: What are gods without followers? Here, Cultists and Dark Apostles alike plot to bring converts to the worship of Chaos—not a hard task on Gladius, once people see the inhuman Xenos, the undoubted effects of the Dark Gods’ powers, and the Daemonic shapes lingering in the chancel.

buildings.name: Construction
buildings.description: Building that constructs new buildings as well as generates ore and influence.
buildings.flavour: Though the Warpsmiths’ Soul Forges are deep in the Realm of Chaos and hence inaccessible from Gladius, Chaos is nothing if not flexible. These Warp Forges are kept hot by the daily sacrifice of thousands of civilians, captured in the ruins of their fallen Hive World, to pull the warpbound buildings of Chaos into shimmering existence.

buildings.name: Energy
buildings.flavour: The fallen Techpriests of Chaos—now the Warpsmiths of the Dark Mechanicum—have had ten thousand years of calibrating their devices beyond the strictures of the Omnissiah. As powerful as a conventional Plasma Generator, this power source can be constructed quickly in situ. Its demon spirit draws energy from the flickering of a tear into the Empyrean to charge an infernal motion device.

buildings.name: Headquarters
buildings.flavour: Even ten thousand years of heresy hasn’t entirely eliminated a Traitor’s training. Like their fellow Adeptus Astartes, Traitor Marines prefer to operate from a secure, well-constructed defensive position—preferably built by the Iron Warriors. This acts as a forward operations base for their raids and pillaging.

buildings.name: Heroes
buildings.description: Building that produces heroes as well as generates influence and increases loyalty.
buildings.flavour: To call any Chaos Space Marine—murders, sadists, psychopaths and monsters to a man—a ‘hero’ is a contradiction-in-terms. But there are exceptional examples of them, the Sorcerers, Masters and Champions of Chaos who head up warbands and follow the diktats and commands of the Gods. Here, they congregate, under the watchful eyes of their Lord.

buildings.name: Food
buildings.flavour: Your troops are mostly beyond mortal desires—but the beastmen, mutants and slaves who run your cities aren’t. To provide food for them, bodies of all sorts are brought to the rendering stations, to provide pleasure for the Slaaneshi degenerates who run them and food for the massed workers—the stronger ones, at least. The weaker ones are dinner.

buildings.name: Housing
buildings.flavour: Of all the gods, only Father Nurgle seems to care for his worshippers. And his worshippers care for the slaves who operate the city, confining them in the perfect quarters to breed disease and pestilence, whilst keeping enough of them physically and mentally robust to perform the many horrifying roles their fallen Astartes masters demand of them.

buildings.name: Infantry
buildings.description: Building that produces infantry as well as generates food and research.
buildings.flavour: Not all Chaos Space Marines date from the 30th millenium—others are recruited from civilians, brutally altered with geneseed taken from a fallen Marine. At this genelab, fallen Apothecaries operate on the strongest cultists drawn from Gladius’ ruined Hives. The few who survive the Abominators’ operations are implanted with Progenoid glands and recruited as new Chaos Space Marines.

buildings.name: Influence
buildings.flavour: Chaos Undivided is a contradiction in terms. Looking at the Daemons of each God—the giggling Horrors, the droning Plaguebearers, the raging Bloodletters, the gasping Daemonettes— nothing could be more dissimilar. Yet this altar reveals the brutal commonality behind Chaos: A dark stone. Gore-soaked ground. The raised knife. And the bacchanalia.

buildings.name: Loyalty
buildings.flavour: It can’t have been a follower of Khorne who named this plain a ‘meadow’—allegory isn’t a concomitant of the Blood God’s troops. Whoever coined it, the metaphor is apt—the carefully-planted rows, tended conscientiously, the gaps refilled as they empty. But the Slaaneshi garden these fields, constantly devising unholy pleasures for their God’s honour at the expense of its victims.

buildings.name: Ore
buildings.flavour: Even the Orks have better ways of getting metal out of the ground than this—but then, the Lords of Chaos’ concern with their servants is less about preventing suffering and more about ensuring it. These mines are crudely cruel, designed to elicit hope, before crushing it. They farm tortured souls for Chaos as much as they do ore.

buildings.name: Vehicles
buildings.description: Building that produces ground vehicles as well as generates ore and influence.
buildings.flavour: Normally confined to the Soul Forges of the Warp, these incomprehensible mechanoid structures are responsible for the creation of all Daemon vehicles. Here, Mechatendril-wreathed Warpsmiths oversee the breaking and corruption of Machine Spirits of captured Imperial vehicles, as well as the forcible incorporation of Lesser Daemons, machinery and tortured flesh into Daemon Engines.

buildings.name: Research
buildings.flavour: On Daemon worlds, storytellers tells of a warp-lost library that contains all of the thoughts of Tzeentch. In its richness, they say, it rivals the Aeldari’s Black Library or the meaningless infinity of the Library of Babel. Whether Tzeentch’s memoirs exist, an Archive of the Ways is a real-world reflection of that false-world myth—a place where truths can be created, not discovered.

upgrades.name: Aircraft
upgrades.description: Building that produces heldrakes as well as generates loyalty and influence.
upgrades.flavour: 10,000 years ago the Heldrakes were fighter craft, piloted by the cream of the Adeptus Astartes. Now, they are hideous amalgams of man and machine, formed by millennia of war into dragon-like creatures that live to fight. This artificial eyrie allows the Warpsmiths and Master of Possession to monitor the Heldrakes and even attempt to replicate their age-old creation.

upgrades.name: ArcaneOcculum
upgrades.description: Grants Champions of Chaos the chance to gain permanently increased accuracy when killing an enemy (Boon of Chaos).
upgrades.flavour: A blood-shot eye pushes through the flesh.

upgrades.name: BlastDamage
upgrades.description: Increases the armour penetration of grenade, missile and blast weapons.
upgrades.flavour: The Warpsmiths may have only trapped minor horrors in the casings of these explosive shells, but their rage at the point of impact isn’t minor—as they shatter and return to the warp, they rage and snatch at anything nearby.

upgrades.name: Bloated
upgrades.description: Grants Champions of Chaos the chance to restore their hitpoints when killing an enemy.
upgrades.flavour: Though Nurgle’s cursed diseases rot a man both physically and spiritually, they also imbue their subjects decaying flesh with inhuman resilience. To such bloated forms, spreading their pox can often bring with it minor blessings from the plague God.

upgrades.name: ChaosLandRaider
upgrades.description: Massively armoured and heavily armed transport unit.
upgrades.flavour: The Chaos Land Raider is the heaviest ground vehicle in a Chaos Space Marine army. Its adamantine and ceramite plates can withstand all but the deadliest anti-tank weaponry, and the blessings of the Warpsmiths keep it at peak efficiency. The twin lascannons mounted in each sponson make short work of other vehicles that would dare to attempt to stop its rampage.

upgrades.name: ChaosRising
upgrades.description: Reduces the cost of founding new cities.
upgrades.flavour: The Imperial population of Gladius know little of Chaos, but in the hell of the Xenos invasions their faith in the distant Emperor has been shaken. It is easy for your cultists and apostles to turn their minds to the Gods—and to their doom.

upgrades.name: BoltDamage
upgrades.description: Increases the armour penetration of bolt weapons.
upgrades.flavour: Bridging the promethium-powered Inferno Bolts of the Imperium and the psychically-powered Inferno Bolts of the Thousand Sons Traitor Legion, Warpborne Bolt skip through the Warp to unleash superheated chemical fire upon their targets.

upgrades.name: ChaosSpawn
upgrades.description: Fast melee infantry unit that mutates each turn.
upgrades.flavour: Although physically powerful and extremely resilient, Chaos Spawn are insane, mewling creatures with no mental powers or self-awareness. Their former intelligence has been sacrificed to their failed ambition. Many a champion of great promise has ended up as a seething mound of bone and blubber, monstrous and screaming with lunatic rage.

upgrades.name: CityTier2
upgrades.description: Increases the tile acquisition radius of cities.
upgrades.flavour: The people of the Imperium will listen to any lies, believe any tale, which tells them that they’re not doomed. That way, sadly, lies perdition, and the gates of Chaos stand wide open to the lost and the damned—at least, on the way in.

upgrades.name: CityTier3
upgrades.description: Increases the tile acquisition radius of cities.
upgrades.flavour: The worshippers of Chaos have shed their pretences. Where before they drew souls to them by their weaknesses or by daemon seduction, now they do it by whips and chains. Packs of slavers and warbands hunt their city’s hinterland for lives to sacrifice. Only the strongest can escape their reach; the weak are grist to the mill for Chaos.

upgrades.name: Construction
upgrades.description: Building that constructs new buildings as well as generates ore and influence.
upgrades.flavour: Though the Warpsmiths’ Soul Forges are deep in the Realm of Chaos and hence inaccessible from Gladius, Chaos is nothing if not flexible. These Warp Forges are kept hot by the daily sacrifice of thousands of civilians, captured in the ruins of their fallen Hive World, to pull the warpbound buildings of Chaos into shimmering existence.

upgrades.name: CrystallineBody
upgrades.description: Grants Champions of Chaos the chance to gain permanently increased hitpoints when killing an enemy (Boon of Chaos).
upgrades.flavour: The champion's flesh changes to diamond.

upgrades.name: DarkDisciple
upgrades.description: Infantry unit that increases the defenses of Chaos units.
upgrades.flavour: Dark Disciples carry profane accoutrements of their masters’ worship and parrot the fell words spoken in his baleful prayers. Many such disciples have been augmented to better serve in their role–their skin stretched out and inked with grim litanies, or their mouths fitted with Daemon-touched vox-grilles to project their voices into the warp. Amidst the din of combat they join their Dark Apostle’s chants, crying out for the Chaos Gods to manifest their blessings.

upgrades.name: Defiler
upgrades.description: Enormous walker unit with devastating melee and ranged weaponry.
upgrades.flavour: Defilers are truly massive beasts of war, twice the size of most other Daemon Engines and with a temperament to match. The ground shivers and melts as they stalk towards their foes on six massive, segmented legs, their great pincer-arms twitching and snipping with an impatient need to slice through warm flesh. The Defiler's crab-like body supports a daemonic torso that carries an array of deadly weaponry, ranging from reaper autocannons to racks of highly explosive missiles. It is the battle cannon mounted in its chest turret, however, that is undoubtedly its most potent armament. Each hell-forged shell that thunders out from its growling muzzle is capable of crippling a squad of Space Marines in a single earth-shaking blast.

upgrades.name: DirgeCaster
upgrades.description: Grants Chaos Rhinos, Defilers and Chaos Land Raiders the ability to prevent overwatch attacks.
upgrades.flavour: This device emits a series of terrifying wails, screams and howls that demoralise and confuse enemies who hear them.

upgrades.name: DaemonPrince
upgrades.description: Monstrous hero that cripples foes with psychic powers before clawing them to death.
upgrades.flavour: Daemon Princes are infernal monsters that tower over the mortals they lead to battle. These paragons of evil take many forms, though all exude a palpable aura of terror and power. In battle, a Daemon Prince strides through the pitiful bullets of the enemy without pause, his unnatural laughter driving men to the edge of fear. Warp energy sizzles from his eyes, and black flames curl from his mouth as he speaks dread phrases that kill as sure as any blade. These are creatures of nightmare—a living expression of Chaos given form.

upgrades.name: ExtraInfantryArmour
upgrades.description: Increases the armour of infantry.
upgrades.flavour: Most infantry in the 41st millenium are equipped with flak armour or its equivalent. If a commander wants their troops to have more than a slight chance of survival, they'll equip them with something closer to the Astra Militarum armaplas-derived carapace armour.

upgrades.name: ExtraVehicleArmour
upgrades.description: Increases the armour of vehicles.
upgrades.flavour: Adding extra armour plates to tanks might be the height of heresy for Tech-Priests, but for the soldiers of the Astra Militarum it's the norm. Ablative plating or custom armour for dealing with particular weapons isn't unheard of.

upgrades.name: FragGrenade
upgrades.description: Grants Chaos Lords, Chaos Space Marines, Havocs, Khorne Berzerkers, Masters of Possession and Warpsmiths the ability to throw anti-infantry grenades.
upgrades.flavour: The lethal storm of shrapnel from these grenades drives opponents further under the cover for a few precious moments, allowing attackers more time to close in and, hopefully, get the first blow in against a disoriented foe.

upgrades.name: HammerOfWrath
upgrades.description: Grants Daemon Princes, Defilers, Helbrutes, Maulerfiends, Venomcrawlers and Warp Talons the ability to perform more devastating attacks.
upgrades.flavour: Many warriors hurl themselves headlong into combat, seeking to crush or trample the foe.

upgrades.name: GiftOfMutation
upgrades.description: Grants Chaos Space Marines, Havocs and Khorne Berzerkers one random unlocked Boon of Chaos.
upgrades.flavour: The Dark Gods have granted their champion a malign reward, which is as likely to be a razor-sharp appendage as it is to be an inconveniently placed tongue.

upgrades.name: Havoc
upgrades.description: Long range infantry unit that is more accurate while stationary.
upgrades.flavour: Some Chaos Space Marine squads carry a high proportion of heavy weapons, the better to annihilate the hated foe. Known as Havocs, these squads provide devastating anti-infantry and anti-armour firepower, dominating large swathes of the battlefield with volley after punishing volley.

upgrades.name: HavocLauncher
upgrades.description: Grants Chaos Rhinos and Chaos Land Raiders a mid-range blast weapon.
upgrades.flavour: These launchers fire clusters of highly explosive missiles.

upgrades.name: Helbrute
upgrades.description: Walker unit that goes crazed when damaged.
upgrades.flavour: Helbrutes are twisted mockeries of the Space Marine Dreadnoughts they used to be, combining the firepower of a small tank with the mind of a frenzied maniac. Each Helbrute holds a living creature within its plated metal chest—a Chaos Space Marine driven over the edge of madness by a never-ending cycle of war.

upgrades.name: Housing
upgrades.description: Building that increases population limit.
upgrades.flavour: Of all the gods, only Father Nurgle seems to care for his worshippers. And his worshippers care for the slaves who operate the city, confining them in the perfect quarters to breed disease and pestilence, whilst keeping enough of them physically and mentally robust to perform the many horrifying roles their fallen Astartes masters demand of them.

upgrades.name: IconOfDespair
upgrades.description: Icon of Chaos that increases the melee damage reduction against fearful enemies to a unit with Mark of Nurgle.
upgrades.flavour: This icon is surrounded by a miasma of disease and hopelessness, turning the thoughts of any nearby foes to the grisly and inevitable deaths that await them.

upgrades.name: IconOfExcess
upgrades.description: Icon of Chaos that increases the damage reduction of a unit with Mark of Slaanesh.
upgrades.flavour: Depravity hangs about this icon like cloying musk, driving those below it into an orgy of sensation-seeking that can only be halted by the total destruction of their bodies.

upgrades.name: IconOfFlame
upgrades.description: Icon of Chaos that grants “attacks deal Soul Blaze damage each turn” to a unit with Mark of Tzeentch.
upgrades.flavour: Coruscating energies surround the icon, swathing the weapons of the devout with mutagenic flames.

upgrades.name: IconOfVengeance
upgrades.description: Icon of Chaos that grants Fearless to a unit with any Mark of Chaos.
upgrades.flavour: These icons shine brightly in the Warp, gathering the malefic energies of Chaos to those who bear them and spurring them on to acts of suicidal brabery in their quest to seize victory from the minions of the Corpse-god.

upgrades.name: Heroes
upgrades.description: Building that produces heroes as well as generates influence and increases loyalty.
upgrades.flavour: To call any Chaos Space Marine—murders, sadists, psychopaths and monsters to a man—a ‘hero’ is a contradiction-in-terms. But there are exceptional examples of them, the Sorcerers, Masters and Champions of Chaos who head up warbands and follow the diktats and commands of the Gods. Here, they congregate, under the watchful eyes of their Lord.

upgrades.name: IconOfWrath
upgrades.description: Icon of Chaos that increases the damage of a unit with Mark of Khorne.
upgrades.flavour: The red-hot curses of the Blood God resound in the minds of those in the shadow of this icon, compelling them to hurl themselves into the fray with wild abandon.

upgrades.name: Infantry
upgrades.description: Building that produces infantry as well as generates food and research.
upgrades.flavour: Not all Chaos Space Marines date from the 30th millenium—others are recruited from civilians, brutally altered with geneseed taken from a fallen Marine. At this genelab, fallen Apothecaries operate on the strongest cultists drawn from Gladius’ ruined Hives. The few who survive the Abominators’ operations are implanted with Progenoid glands and recruited as new Chaos Space Marines.

upgrades.name: KhorneBerzerker
upgrades.description: Melee infantry unit.
upgrades.flavour: It was the gruesome experiments of Angron, Primarch of the World Eaters, that led to the creation of the first Berzerkers. By the ritual lobotomisation of his warriors, he removed all sense of fear and danger and then heightened the rush his soldiers experienced in combat. When the Legion swore itself to Khorne, the Berzerkers were no longer bound by Imperial battle doctrine and were given full rein to exercise their bloodthirsty skills. They have since become the ultimate close combat shock troops, entering an uncontrollable frenzy in the heat of battle.

upgrades.name: LasDamage
upgrades.description: Increases the armour penetration of las and plasma weapons.
upgrades.flavour: Going beyond the Imperium’s proscribed technologies has allowed the Dark Mechanicum to unlock more lethal and more horrifying weapon capabilities.

upgrades.name: Loyalty
upgrades.description: Building that increases loyalty.
upgrades.flavour: It can’t have been a follower of Khorne who named this plain a ‘meadow’—allegory isn’t a concomitant of the Blood God’s troops. Whoever coined it, the metaphor is apt—the carefully-planted rows, tended conscientiously, the gaps refilled as they empty. But the Slaaneshi garden these fields, constantly devising unholy pleasures for their God’s honour at the expense of its victims.

upgrades.name: MarkOfKhorne
upgrades.description: Mark of Chaos that increases the attacks of an allied Chaos non-psyker infantry unit.
upgrades.flavour: The Mark of Khorne is bestowed only upon those whose relentless rage and boundless ferocity pays due homage to the Blood Good's own. To such disciples, Khorne grants an unholy wrath that burns as hot as the stars.

upgrades.name: KrakGrenade
upgrades.description: Grants Chaos Lord, Chaos Space Marines, Havocs, Khorne Berzerkers, Master of Possession and Warpsmith the ability to throw anti-armour grenades.
upgrades.flavour: Krak grenades are implosive charges designed to crack vehicle armour.

upgrades.name: MarkOfNurgle
upgrades.description: Mark of Chaos that increases the hitpoints of an allied Chaos infantry unit.
upgrades.flavour: Nurgle's blessing manifests not only as a suite of virulent plagues and diseases, but also as the inhuman constitution needed to survive them.

upgrades.name: MarkOfSlaanesh
upgrades.description: Mark of Chaos that increases the movement of an allied Chaos infantry unit.
upgrades.flavour: The devotees of Slaanesh have their senses and reactions heightened to a supernatural degree, all the better to drink in the extreme, multifaceted stimuli of the battlefield. A warrior gifted in this manner will move with uncanny grace and speed, his blade lashing out like the tongue of a serpent as he revels in the ugly spectacle of death.

upgrades.name: MarkOfTzeentch
upgrades.description: Mark of Chaos that increases the invulnerable damage reduction of an allied Chaos infantry unit.
upgrades.flavour: Those dedicated to Tzeentch enjoy the protection and prescience of the Master of Manipulation.

upgrades.name: MasterOfPossession
upgrades.description: Psyker hero unit that summons Daemons and supports allies.
upgrades.flavour: Masters of Possession lead warbands of devoted warriors in pursuit of untold power. These sorcerous figures have mastered the darkest and most blasphemous lore: the art of using hosts of living flesh to house daemonic spirits. It is they who perform the profane ceremonies of binding that imbue the Daemonkin with their warp-born power. Gouging a breach in the fabric of realspace, the Master of Possession draws a willing entity from the immaterium, channelling its terrible energies into the body of a supplicant or the chassis of a war machine. So thoroughly are these dread figures steeped in blasphemous sorcery that where they walk, reality itself recoils.

upgrades.name: Mechanoid
upgrades.description: Grants Champions of Chaos the chance to gain permanently increased armour when killing an enemy (Boon of Chaos).
upgrades.flavour: The champion's flesh bonds with his armour.

upgrades.name: Maulerfiend
upgrades.description: Fast walker unit that reduces the melee attacks of adjacent units.
upgrades.flavour: The Daemon Engines known as Maulerfiends thunder towards the foe like monstrous attack dogs loosed from the leash. Their eyes glow with balefire as ectoplasmic drool drizzles from their fanged maws. Their thick front limbs end in articulated claws powerful enough to tear a Dreadnought limb from limb. Should they catch a squad of infantry, they will scissor them apart or crush them into paste with a flex of their massive talons.

upgrades.name: MeleeDamage
upgrades.description: Increases the armour penetration of melee weapons.
upgrades.flavour: It’s normal for soldiers to grow close to a trusted weapon—but the marines of the Traitor Legions have gone further. Over the centuries, the troops of the Adeptus Astartes have literally grown into their weaponry, becoming one with their guns and blades, exponentially increasing their effectiveness.

upgrades.name: Obliterator
upgrades.description: Elite infantry unit with cyclable weapons.
upgrades.flavour: The monstrous warriors of the Obliterator cults are a blasphemy against nature and Machine God alike. Their forms are so altered, so thoroughly conjoined with the tools of war, that every cell in their bodies thrills with a spark of mechanical life. Only the Dark Mechanicum have mastered the complete fusion of metal and flesh, melding the inert and the animate together on a spiritual level in order to form something far greater than mere cybernetics. Because of their Chaos-born powers, Obliterators are capable of not only absorbing weaponry into themselves, but also of manifesting munitions from their titanium-laced flesh.

upgrades.name: NoctilithCrown
upgrades.description: Grants Chaos Cultists the ability to construct fortifications.
upgrades.flavour: Noctilith Crowns form vital strongpoints, for these arcane devices can draw in the raw energy of Chaos itself.

upgrades.name: OurLivesForTheGods
upgrades.description: Increases the growth rate of Cultist Sacrifice.
upgrades.flavour: So many now lie dead at cultists’ blades on Gladius that each death is meaningless, empty, shallow. But it also increases the effect of their sacrifice, as they drag this world closer to the Dark Gods’ fallen hell dimension, and it becomes easier for dark boons to breach the barrier with the Immaterium.

upgrades.name: MeltaBomb
upgrades.description: Grants Chaos Lord, Chaos Space Marines, Havocs and Khorne Berzerkers the ability to deploy a melta bomb that is highly effective against heavy vehicles and fortifications.
upgrades.flavour: Melta bombs are fusion charges designed to burn through an armoured hull in a matter of seconds.

upgrades.name: RiteOfBlood
upgrades.description: Sacrifices population to Khorne to increase the production output of units in the city.
upgrades.flavour: Khorne may have other, minor, traits—a certain nobility and simplicity of war—but his lust for death and blood outweighs them by far. Rites in his name bring not only his blessing, but also increase the work rate of the slave populace, in their terror that they could be next.

upgrades.name: RiteOfChange
upgrades.description: Sacrifices population to Tzeentch to increase the production output of Warp Forges and research output of Archives of the Ways in the city.
upgrades.flavour: Invoking the Changer’s name is highly risky—few know what he will do to further his endless plans, or the curses he brings if he is distracted to no purpose. After a Rite of Change, some mutate, some disappear, some are embedded alive into the city walls—but always something is learned.

upgrades.name: RiteOfPestilence
upgrades.description: Sacrifices population to Nurgle to increase the food output of Renderers and the growth rate in the city.
upgrades.flavour: A Rite of Pestilence doesn’t explicitly sacrifice to Nurgle—it merely invites his blessing upon your people. Given the virulence of Nurgle’s diseases—the Rot, the Chortling Murrain, the Oozing Pox—many will die of these blessings, in his name. Many others will live with them and burgeon with plague-ridden fecundity.

upgrades.name: RiteOfUnholyPleasure
upgrades.description: Sacrifices population to Slaanesh to increase the influence output of Altars of Chaos and loyalty output of Meadows of Sorrow in the city.
upgrades.flavour: Stop your ears with wax, bind your mouth, stitch up your eyes, and tie yourself down. Only then invoke Slaanesh, so that you may not succumb utterly to the Pleasure God’s irresistible desires.

upgrades.name: SmokeLauncher
upgrades.description: Grants Chaos Rhinos, Defilers and Chaos Land Raiders the ability to launch a smoke screen that increases the ranged damage reduction.
upgrades.flavour: Some vehicles have small launchers mounted onto them that carry smoke canisters. These are used to temporarily obscure the vehicle behind billowing clouds of smoke, allowing it to cross open areas in greater safety—although it does so at the cost of being able to fire its own weapons.

upgrades.name: TemporalDistortion
upgrades.description: Grants Champions of Chaos the chance to gain permanently increased movement when killing an enemy (Boon of Chaos).
upgrades.flavour: Time is altered around the champion.

upgrades.name: Vehicles
upgrades.description: Building that produces ground vehicles as well as generates ore and influence.
upgrades.flavour: Normally confined to the Soul Forges of the Warp, these incomprehensible mechanoid structures are responsible for the creation of all Daemon vehicles. Here, Mechatendril-wreathed Warpsmiths oversee the breaking and corruption of Machine Spirits of captured Imperial vehicles, as well as the forcible incorporation of Lesser Daemons, machinery and tortured flesh into Daemon Engines.

upgrades.name: VeteransOfTheLongWar
upgrades.description: Increases the morale, and increases the melee accuracy of infantry against units of the Space Marines faction.
upgrades.flavour: Many Chaos Space Marine factions have been locked in a constant, grinding war against the Imperium of Man for centuries, if not millennia. The burning hate they feel for their loyalist brothers has had time to fester, now eclipsing all other emotions. This applies, above all, to the original nine Traitor Legions who flocked to Horus' banner ten millennia ago and continue their war against their loyal brethren to this day.

upgrades.name: WarpflameGargoyles
upgrades.description: Grants damage over time to Chaos Rhino, Defiler and Chaos Land Raider weapons.
upgrades.flavour: The muzzles of this vehicle's guns flicker with unnatural fire.

upgrades.name: WarpFrenzy
upgrades.description: Grants Champions of Chaos the chance to gain permanently increased attacks when killing an enemy (Boon of Chaos).
upgrades.flavour: The champion is consumed with anger.

upgrades.name: Venomcrawler
upgrades.description: Terrifying walker unit that consumes the souls of its enemies to restore its hitpoints.
upgrades.flavour: Pounding forwards upon bladed limbs come the horrors known as Venomcrawlers. Grotesque amalgams of metal, flesh and daemonic entities, these monstrosities hiss and snarl as they scuttle towards their prey. Fleshy tongues flap from snarling maws and soulflayer tendrils lash back and forth, all tasting the air for the scent of their enemies' fear. As the Venomcrawlers continue to butcher, their fanged mouths gape ever wider, drawing the souls of those slain into their vast mechanical abdomens.

upgrades.name: Warpsmith
upgrades.description: Hero unit that supports vehicles and boosts the economy.
upgrades.flavour: Warpsmiths are the masters of the machine. Most can trace their origins back to the priesthood of Mars, whether through the schisms of the Magi or the rigid doctrine of the Techmarines. However, where the Adeptus Mechanicus regard technology as sacrosanct, the Warpsmiths seek to subjugate and control it.

upgrades.name: WarpTalon
upgrades.description: Melee infantry unit that can warp across difficult terrain and blind unsuspecting enemies.
upgrades.flavour: When a pack of Warp Talons emerges from the warp, it appears to those on the battlefield below as if daemonic warriors have burst out from nothingness into fiery, vengeful life. Like the stuff of nightmares, they plummet downwards in an explosion of warp fire, tearing into the foe with murderous intent.
